docs.title: Executive summary
docs.text: SAPAA currently manages site inspection data through a manual pipeline. Stewards submit observations via Google Forms, Admin converts them in MS Excel, and the results are stored in a local MS Access database. This project replaces that temporary setup with a sustainable, low-cost cloud data infrastructure that automatically ingests inspection data into a PostgreSQL database, enables Admin to manage the data and generate PDF reports. A major focus of our implementation is scalable and cost-aware image management. Inspection images are stored in AWS S3, providing a reliable, secure, and affordable solution for handling large volumes of media. The primary user is the Admin, who needs a reliable, maintainable system that eliminates manual data handling, while keeping his access to the data as well as report generation and distribution. This project also hopes to create Android and iOS versions of the web application for stewards to bring out into the field and be able to log their observations while offline.

docs.title: Project glossary
docs.text:
• SAPAA: Stewards of Alberta’s Protected Areas Association. A volunteer society that supports the stewardship of Alberta’s protected natural areas.

  • Natural Area: A provincially designated protected land, such as a Provincial Park, Wildland Park, Wilderness Area, Ecological Reserve, or Natural Area, managed by Alberta Parks.

  • Site: A specific Natural Area monitored and reported on by SAPAA stewards.

  • Site Inspection: A record of field observations, ecological conditions, safety notes, and steward activities for a given Site.

  • Steward A SAPAA volunteer responsible for visiting Sites and submitting inspection data.

  • Admin: The SAPAA administrator responsible for managing Site Inspection data, generating official reports, and distributing information to stewards.

  • SAPAA Stewards: The web application that allows stewards to submit Site Inspection data easily and automatically uploads data to the PostgreSQL database.

  • SAPAA Stewards Mobile: The mobile application, usable on both Android and iOS, that stewards can use while offline to submit their Site Inspection data

docs.title: P1 – Implement Site Inspection Web Application for SAPAA
US 1.0.1 – Access Site Inspection Form on Web Application | Story Points: 3
docs.text:
As a User, I want to be able to access the Site Inspection form on the web page, so that I can fill out the Site Inspection Form with my information

Acceptance Tests

  1. Should have the New Site Inspection Report button visible and enabled
  2. Should navigate to the new report page when clicking the "New Site Inspection Report" button
  3. Blocks submission and shows the required questions popup when a mandatory field is missing
  4. Successfully calls uploadSiteInspectionAnswers when all required questions are answered

docs.title: US 1.0.2 – Add Personal Information to Site Inspection Form | Story Points: 1
docs.text:
As a User, I want to be able to add my personal details, so that I can be identified for completing the Site Inspection.

Acceptance Tests

  1. User can enter steward name
  2. User can enter first and last names of guests
  3. User can enter contact information (email and phone)
  4. User can indicate SAPAA membership
  5. Footer tracks progress correctly

docs.title: US 1.0.3 – Liability Check | Story Points: 1
docs.text:
As a User, I want to be prompted to verify that I am not a volunteer and this is not an emergency, so that I can ensure I am accessing the correct resource(s).

Acceptance Tests

  1. System displays a loading spinner followed by a mandatory verification popup before form access is granted
  2. Popup explicitly displays an emergency notice regarding 911 and a "310-LAND" contact link
  3. System requires the user to type an exact, case-sensitive phrase (shown in a code block) to proceed
  4. System displays real-time validation errors for incorrect, partial, or trailing-space phrase entries
  5. Verified stewards bypass the liability popup entirely and see a "Steward Badge" in the header
  6. Users can click "Cancel" to exit the process, which triggers a navigation back to the previous page.
  7. The popup state is fresh upon re-navigation, ensuring users cannot "trick" the system by going back and forward.

docs.title: US 1.0.4 – Have access to the Terms and Conditions of Inputting Information | Story Points: 1
docs.text:
As a User, I want to be able to see the Terms and Conditions of filling out the Site Inspection Form, so that I am aware of how my information will be used for and the level of privacy I am agreeing to.

Acceptance Tests

  1. "Continue to Form" button remains disabled by default and only enables when the Terms and Conditions checkbox is explicitly checked
  2. "Continue" button reacts dynamically to checkbox toggling, and non-steward verification blocks form access until all terms are accepted
  3. Keyboard-accessible link to the Terms is available within the popup; clicking it allows viewing terms without closing the active verification state
  4. The terms link includes a from query parameter for tracking, and the "checked" state is preserved after the popup is dismissed to record the agreement.

docs.title: US 1.0.5 – Add Details Regarding the Overview of my Visit | Story Points: 1
docs.text:
As a User, I want to be able to add details regarding my visit, so that I can describe which site I went to and when I visited it.

Acceptance Tests

  1. User can enter date of visit
  2. User can enter which site they are inspecting
  3. User can select their designated steward status
  4. User can select only ONE designated steward option (radio button behavior)
  5. Displays all required fields with Required badge
  6. Footer tracks progress correctly
  7. Allows submission when all required fields are filled
  8. Displays error when submitting without required fields

docs.title: US 1.0.6 – Rank the Health of the Site | Story Points: 1
docs.text:
As a User, I want to be able to rank the state of the site during my visit, so that I can describe its health and my thoughts on its current condition.

Acceptance Tests

  1. Renders the overall impression section and reaches questions 2.1 to 2.3
  2. User can select naturalness score "4 = Great"
  3. User can select naturalness score "3 = Good"
  4. User can select naturalness score "2 = Passable"
  5. User can select naturalness score "1 = Bad"
  6. User can select naturalness score "0 = Terrible"
  7. User can enter comments on how healthy they felt the site was
  8. User can enter comments about changes from their previous visit
  9. User can clear change-in-conditions comments if not applicable

docs.title: US 1.0.7 – Add Details Regarding How the Trip Went | Story Points: 1
docs.text:
As a User, I want to be able to add details regarding how my trip went, so that I can describe the duration and the reason for my visit.

Acceptance Tests

  1. User can enter reasoning for visiting the site (Q41) and additional details (Q41.1)
  2. User can input duration of trip and comments (Q42)
  3. User can input visit details (Q43)
  4. Q41 and Q42 are required; Q41.1 and Q43 are not
  5. Footer shows error for missing required Q41/Q42 but accepts missing optional Q41.1/Q43

docs.title: US 1.0.8 – Address What Amenities are in the Site | Story Points: 1
docs.text:
As a User, I want to be able to add details regarding ease of use of the site, so that I can be as detailed as possible in my report.

Acceptance Tests

  1. User can select amenities options for ease to visit
  2. User can select signage and trails options for ease-of-use details
  3. User can unselect a previously selected ease-to-visit option

docs.title: US 1.0.9 – Designation as a Protected Site | Story Points: 1
docs.text:
As a User, I want to indicate how I know the site is a protected area, so that it can be ensured that the sites are properly designated as protected areas.

Acceptance Tests

  1. User can indicate protected status by selecting signage
  2. User can indicate protected status by selecting fencing
  3. User can select "Signage" as protected-area evidence
  4. User can select "Fencing" as protected-area evidence
  5. User can select "Exists but in disrepair" as protected-area evidence
  6. User can select "Not Applicable" as protected-area evidence
  7. User can deselect a protected-area indicator option

docs.title: US 1.0.10 – Indicate submissions to iNaturalist | Story Points: 1
docs.text:
As a User, I want to be told about iNaturalist and indicate if I am posting to it, so that it can be documented if my findings have yet been shared to iNaturalist (Q53).

Acceptance Tests

  1. Renders section 4 and the 4.2 Submissions to iNaturalist question
  2. User can select "Yes" for submissions to iNaturalist
  3. User can select "No, Not this time" for submissions to iNaturalist
  4. User can select "No, not a member of iNaturalist" for submissions to iNaturalist
  5. User can select "What is iNaturalist?" for submissions to iNaturalist
  6. User can select "Other/Not Applicable" for submissions to iNaturalist
  7. Selecting a new iNaturalist option replaces the previous one

docs.title: US 1.0.11 – Address details of Landscape changes | Story Points: 2
docs.text:
As a User, I want to be able to add details regarding any significant site changes, so that important or significant changes can be tracked in my report

Acceptance Tests

  1. User can enter details about recent landscape changes (Q54)
  2. Q54 is optional and submitting without it does not show an error

docs.title: US 1.0.12 – Address any Biological Observations that is in the Site | Story Points: 1
docs.text:
As a User, I want to be able to add details regarding any biological observations that I saw or noticed on the site so that I can update the site’s information with new / changing / consistent wildlife sightings.

Acceptance Tests

  1. Allows the user to enter biological wildlife observations
  2. Allows the user to delete text from the biological observations box and ensures it is empty
  3. Does not include question number 4.3 in the missing required questions popup when answered

docs.title: US 1.0.13 - Address Any Human Disturbances - Section 8 | Story Points: 1
docs.text:
As a User, I want to be able to add details regarding any human disturbances I noticed during my visit, so that I can be as detailed as possible in my report

Acceptance Tests

  1. Renders section 5 questions 5.1 through 5.8
  2. User can indicate what other visitors were doing
  3. User can indicate agricultural activity
  4. User can indicate resource extraction activity
  5. User can indicate motorized disturbance
  6. User can indicate gathering and dumping activity
  7. User can indicate infrastructure encroachment
  8. User can enter invasive plants or disease comments
  9. User can enter comments on human disturbances
  10. Comments can be cleared when not applicable

docs.title: US 1.0.14 - Add Other Comments | Story Points: 2
docs.text:
As a User, I want to be able to add comments/information that aren’t specifically mentioned in the questions, so that I can share all information I see as important, even when it isn’t specifically asked for.

Acceptance Tests

  1. User can enter their comments in beThere section
  2. User can enter their comments in notThere section
  3. User can enter their comments in 2BDone section
  4. User can enter their comments in Close section
  5. Does not include comments in the missing required questions popup when answered

docs.title: US 1.0.15 – Inform SAPAA of Any Restorative Work that Needs to be Done / Was Done | Story Points: 2
docs.text:
As a User, I want to be able to add details regarding any actions I believe need to be taken upon the land or that I took, so that I can relay the necessary restoration information to the right bodies of power.

Acceptance Tests

  1. Renders section 6 questions 6.1 through 6.4
  2. User can indicate urgently needed restorative actions
  3. User can add nearby resident contact information
  4. User can indicate actions they have taken to help restore/protect the site
  5. User can add general comments
  6. Comments can be cleared when not applicable

docs.title: US 1.0.16 – Add Any Photography Captured During Visit | Story Points: 5
docs.text:
As a User, I want to be able to add any photography taken during my visit, so that I can use photos to help make my report clearer and provide visual evidence of my observations.

Acceptance Tests

  1. Able to add pictures taken during the user's visit. The user should be able to add any final remarks as well
  2. Able to remove the uploaded media if needed
  3. Able to replace the uploaded media by clicking on it
  4. Submitting the Site Inspection Form without uploading questions will not result in any error messaging and will be accepted.

docs.title: US 1.0.17 – (Admin) Add Questions Site Inspections Form | Story Points: 3
docs.text:
As an admin, I want to be able to add questions on the Site Inspection Form, so that I can add new questions as needed.

Acceptance Tests

  1. Able to add new questions to the Site Inspection Form and save the form.
  2. Other users who access the Site Inspection Form will be able to see the new questions
  3. Users who are not admins cannot add questions to the form

docs.title: US 1.0.18 – Adding Image Caption | Story Points: 2
docs.text:
As a User, I want to be able to add captions to the images that I upload, so that context can be given for the images.

Acceptance Tests

  1. Able to view the image caption by clicking on it
  2. Able to add an image caption if no image caption is present
  3. Able to modify an image caption
  4. Able to remove an image caption

docs.title: US 1.0.19 - Admin Viewing Images and Metadata | Story Points: 2
docs.text:
As an Admin. I want to be able to view the images uploaded by the users, so that I can keep track of site inspection and monitor site well-being.

Acceptance Tests

  1. Admin can click a button to look at all uploaded images, their metadata, and the site they are associated with
  2. Admin can remove the image if it’s not appropriate

docs.title: US 1.0.20 – Admin Editing Image Metadata | Story Points: 3
docs.text:
As an Admin. I want to be able to edit image metadata so that I can make sure that the image data is accurate for the report's compliance.

Acceptance Tests

  1. Admin can access an image’s metadata
  2. Admin can change the metadata
  3. Admin can save the changes to the metadata
  4. Other users can see the updated image’s metadata

docs.title: TASK 1.0.21 - View and understand the Supabase and decide if it is suitable
docs.text: Get acquainted with the existing super-base and decide if it is necessary to modify or rebuild it, or migrate to a different database management system

docs.title: US 1.0.22 – (User) Edit My Site Inspections Form | Story Points: 5
docs.text:
As a User, I want to be able to modify my Site Inspection forms after the fact, so that I can make edits to my forms as needed.

Acceptance Tests

  1. If user modifies a previous form, the form is updated to show the new info
  2. If user attempts to modify their forms but cancels the information reverts and is not change
  3. If user attempts to modify their form the form is prefilled with the current data
  4. If the user attempts to modify their form, they cannot submit the modifications if required information / questions are cleared / disabled
  5. The user cannot un-check their agreement to the terms and conditions (would have to delete their report entirely if they required that)

docs.title: US 1.0.23 – Non-Public Information | Story Points: 2
docs.text:
As a User. I want to have somewhere to write information that won’t be published publically so that sensitive information / information for SAPAA only isn’t leaked

Acceptance Tests

  1. System ensures that name, email, and user_id are never included in the site inspection answers payload
  2. User roles and avatar URLs are explicitly excluded from the database submission for inspection records
  3. The submission payload is restricted to only the four allowed data columns; no unauthorized keys are permitted
  4. The uid is used only for internal report linking and is never stored within the publicly accessible answers array
  5. The response_id in the database refers to the report itself, not the private ID of the user who submitted it
  6. Automated checks confirm that sensitive user strings (like the actual email text) never appear within any submitted row values

docs.title: US 1.0.24 – Modify my Site Inspections Form Questions | Story Points: 3
docs.text:
As an admin, I want to be able to modify the questions on the Site Inspection Form, so that I can make any changes / correct any errors as I see fit.

Acceptance Tests

  1. Able to modify questions in the Site Inspection Form to add, remove, or change information from a particular question
  2. Other users who access the Site Inspection Form will be able to see the modified questions
  3. If admin begins to edit a question, they can discard edits before officially submitting the change
  4. Non-admin users cannot change or edit any questions

docs.title: US 1.0.25 – Hide a Site Inspections Form Questions | Story Points: 3
docs.text:
As an admin, I want to be able to hide any of the questions on the Site Inspection Form, so that only the questions I want are visible.

Acceptance Tests

  1. If an admin toggles a question to be hidden, users can no longer access it when filling out the form
  2. If an admin toggles a question to be hidden, users can no longer edit their responses to it in previous forms
  3. If an admin toggles a question to be hidden, it will still be shown on existing / past reports
  4. If an admin toggles a question to be visible, users will be able to access it when filling out the form
  5. If an admin toggles a question to be visible, users will be able edit their responses to it in previous forms

docs.title: US 1.0.26 – Persist Site Inspection Form Draft | Story Points: 5
docs.text:
As a user, I want my answers to be automatically saved as a draft, so that I do not lose my progress if I refresh, navigate away, or accidentally close my tab.

Acceptance Tests

  1. Saves responses to local storage on change and restores them after rerendering
  2. Separates drafts by site so Site A data does not appear on Site B
  3. Restores draft when returning to the page after navigating away
  4. Clears draft data from localStorage after successful submission

docs.title: US 1.0.27 – Enforce Required Questions on Site Inspection Form | Story Points: 3
docs.text:
As a user, I want to be prevented from submitting the form if required questions are unanswered, so that the report is complete and contains all mandatory information.

Acceptance Tests

  1. If a user attempts to submit the Site Inspection Form without answering all required questions, a pop up message is displayed indicating that required questions must be completed before submission
  2. Blocks submission and shows the required questions popup when a mandatory field is missing
  3. The form submission is blocked until all required questions are answered
  4. Successfully calls uploadSiteInspectionAnswers when all required questions are answered
  5. Optional questions do not prevent submission if left unanswered

docs.title: US 1.0.28 – Autofill Applicable Form Questions | Story Points: 3
docs.text:
As a user, I want applicable information to be auto-filled into my report form, so that I can save time from having to manually enter that information myself.

Acceptance Tests

  1. Information is auto-filled when a new form is opened
  2. User's name is auto-filled
  3. User's email is auto-filled
  4. User's phone number is auto-filled
  5. Date of visit is auto-filled with the current date
  6. Information is only auto-filled when it exists for the given user (not all user's have all of this information saved on their account)
  7. Auto-filled information can be manually edited afterwards

docs.title: TASK 1.0.29 - Refactor the Database Schema and Produce an Updated ER Diagram
docs.text: Analyze the existing Supabase database schema, identify structural issues and inconsistencies, and refactor the design to better support the Site Inspection Form functionality. Update relationships, normalize tables where necessary, and produce a clear ER diagram that reflects the revised data model.

docs.title: US 2.0.1 – Manage the uploading and storing of site inspection images | Story Points: 8
docs.text:
As an Admin, I want images uploaded from the Site Inspection Form web application to be stored in an AWS S3 bucket and referenced in the database, so that they can be accessed and managed for future reports.

Acceptance Tests

  1. Uploaded images are stored in an AWS S3 bucket
  2. Image metadata and references are stored in the database
  3. Uploaded images are accessible through the application

docs.title: US 2.0.2 – Image Metadata| Story Points: 2
docs.text:
As a User, I want the image I upload to retain its metadata, such as descriptions, so that I do not have to retype previous descriptions.

Acceptance Tests

  1. When a user uploads an image, the system preserves existing metadata
  2. Image descriptions/captions entered during upload are saved with the image.
  3. Stored metadata persists when images are viewed later.

docs.title: US 2.0.3 – Gallery View | Story Points: 3
docs.text:
As a User, I want to be able to see a gallery view of uploaded images, so that I can reference/view multiple images at once.

Acceptance Tests

  1. Users can view multiple images for a site in a gallery layout.
  2. The gallery displays only images associated with the selected site or inspection.
  3. Users can open individual images from the gallery for detailed viewing.
  4. Images added to a report for a site after initially being posted will also be added to the gallery view
  5. Images removed from a report for a site after initially being posted will also be removed from the gallery view

docs.title: US 2.0.4 – Offline Image Viewing | Story Points: 5
docs.text:
As a User, I want to be able to view images offline, so that I can reference previous images where I don’t have internet access

Acceptance Tests

  1. Previously viewed or downloaded images are accessible without an internet connection (airplane mode).
  2. Images load correctly in offline mode without application errors.
  3. Users are informed when images are unavailable due to not being cached.

docs.title: TASK 2.0.5 - Discover other suitable image storage platforms
docs.text: Discover more viable and cheaper solutions to be able to upload and store images online (as opposed to supabase). The budget is under CAD$50 per month.

docs.title: TASK 2.0.6 - Refactor Report Rendering to Use Updated Database Schema
docs.text: Update report rendering logic to fetch and display data using the refactored Supabase schema. Modify queries and joins to align with the new Form Responses and Answers tables and verified correct rendering of all question types.

docs.title: P3 – Site Inspection Mobile Application (Android & iOS)
US 3.0.1 – Access the mobile version of the Site Inspection Form | Story Points: 5
docs.text:
As a User, I want to be able to access the Site Inspection form on the mobile app, so that I can make observations and reports while I’m out in the field.

Acceptance Tests

  1. Users can access the Site Inspection Form on both Android and iOS applications.
  2. The mobile form supports all required inspection fields.
  3. The SIR can be submitted from the mobile application

docs.title: US 3.0.2 – Offline Data Syncing  | Story Points: 8
docs.text:
As a User, I want the information that I gather while offline to be automatically uploaded once I regain connection, so that I don’t have to waste time manually reuploading information.

Acceptance Tests

  2. Offline data is automatically uploaded once connectivity is restored.
  3. Users can see the sync status of pending inspections.

docs.title: US 4.0.1 – View Site Profile of a Particular Site | Story Points: 3
docs.text:
As a User, I want to be able to view a profile for each site, so that I can identify important information about the site I’m travelling to / inspecting

  1. Each site has a dedicated profile page.
  2. Site profiles display key information such as name, location, and inspection history.
  3. Users can navigate from the map or list view to a site profile.
  4. The site profile has some ‘link’ to all previous SIRs in that site

docs.title: US 4.0.2 – Add Site Profile of a Particular Site | Story Points: 2
docs.text:
As an Admin, I want to be able to add a profile for a new site, so that I can keep my app up to date with the latest sites

Acceptance Tests

  1. A site has a specified county
  2. A site has a type
  3. A site has a name

  5. Admins can access a button/option to add a site profile
  6. Non-admin users cannot add a site profile

docs.title: US 4.0.3 – Update Site Profile of a Particular Site | Story Points: 3
docs.text:
As an Admin, I want to be able to update a profile for each site, so that users of the app can stay informed about the state of the site

Acceptance Tests

As an Admin, I want to be able to remove a profile for each site, so that I can keep what crown land is up to date

  1. Site is removed from the app

docs.title: US 4.0.5 – Amenities Information on Site Profile | Story Points: 2
docs.text:
As a User, I want to be able to view amenities information about individual sites, so that I can find and access any amenities I need (parking, washrooms, facilities)

Acceptance Tests

  1. Site profiles display available amenities (e.g., parking, washrooms, facilities).
  2. Amenity information is clearly labelled and easy to locate.
  3. Users can view amenities without navigating away from the site profile.

docs.title: US 4.0.6 – Site-specific Recommended Gear Lists | Story Points: 2
docs.text:
As a User, I want to be able to see site-specific gear recommendations, so that I can be prepared for the specific site I’m inspecting

Acceptance Tests

  1. Each site profile displays a recommended gear list.
  2. Gear recommendations are specific to the selected site.

docs.title: US 5.0.1 – Sign In Feature | Story Points: 2
docs.text:
As a User, I want to be able to sign in to the app so that I can use my previous account.

Acceptance Tests

  1. Correct email and password allow access
  2. Incorrect credentials display an error
  3. User should be forced to input all fields

docs.title: US 5.0.2 – Sign Out Feature | Story Points: 2
docs.text:
As a User, I want to be able to sign out of the app so that I can access the app through a different account.

Acceptance Tests

  1. User is logged out and all tokens are revoked
  2. User is redirected to the home page
  3. Login information remains stored in the database
  4. User can sign back in with the same or a different account
  5. Back navigation does not return to protected screens
  6. If sign out fails, an error message is displayed and the user can try again

docs.title: US 5.0.3 – Edit Account Feature | Story Points: 2
docs.text:
As a User, I want to be able to edit my account information so that I can keep my information up to date.

Acceptance Tests

  1. Updating login-related info requires re-login
  2. Next login works only with updated credentials
  3. User must be logged in to update information
  4. Non-login info updates do not require re-login
  5. Users can only edit their own account and not that of others

docs.title: US 5.0.4 – Disable Account Feature | Story Points: 2
docs.text:
As a User, I want to be able to disable my account so that my login information is no longer stored or accessible.

Acceptance Tests

  1. Disabled accounts cannot log in again
  2. If User disabled their account they should be taken back to the home screen
  3. Users can only disable their own account
  4. A user trying to disable their account should be prompted by a confirmation message first (‘Are you sure you want to disable your account?’)

As a User, I want to enable dark mode for the web and mobile applications so that I can reduce eye strain.

  4. Selecting the current mode causes no change

  2. Users can change font size by selecting one of the other options

  4. UI and information should be legible and responsive regardless of font size
  5. If a user selects the font size they are already using, nothing should change

docs.title: MoSCoW
docs.text:
The MoSCoW method is used to prioritize user stories based on their criticality and impact. Each user story is categorized into one of the following priority levels:

  • Must-have Essential requirements that are critical for the application to function.

  • Should-have Important features that are not strictly essential but add significant value.

  • Could-have Desirable features that enhance the application but are not required for core functionality.

  • Would Like But Won’t Get Features that are out of scope for the current project or deferred for future consideration.

docs.text:

docs.title: Similar Products
docs.text:
• Park Protector
    • High/low frequency inspections, multi-site management, reporting, and scheduling
    • Scheduling inspections across many sites and recurring inspection plans
    • Inspiration: Similar inspection history for each site and export capabilities
    • Useful to SAPAA: A system that monitors inspection reports is similar to SAPAA’s site inspection reports
  • iNaturalist
    • A community platform for sharing and identifying nature observations.
    • Inspiration: offers ideas for building intuitive photo galleries, tagging ecological attributes, and storing long-term environmental data.
    • Relevant to SAPAA: helps shape how inspection data can be organized to show ecological change over time.
  • Avenza Maps
    • A mobile app for offline maps and PDF map layers.
    • Inspiration: highlights clear workflows for downloading, caching, and updating large data bundles for offline use.
    • Relevant to SAPAA: directly applicable to the Field Notes Reader, which requires offline access to inspection data and reports.

docs.title: Open-source Projects
docs.text:
• Supabase

    • What it is: Open-source backend (managed Postgres + Auth + Storage + Edge Functions).
    • How we’ll use it (external interface):
    • PostgreSQL as the system of record for inspections/sites.
    • Storage for images and generated PDF reports.
    • Auth + Row-Level Security (RLS) to separate Admin vs Reader access.
    • Edge Functions / cron to build nightly offline data bundles (JSON + thumbnails + PDFs).
    • Reference/inspiration: Supabase’s PostgREST and RLS patterns for secure CRUD without a custom API layer.
    • Source of insights: Example implementations for file storage policies and signed URLs.
    • Risks/notes: Free-tier and pricing limits can change; large media can impact storage/egress. We’ll set a monthly budget cap in the Project Plan and monitor usage.

  • LimeSurvey

    • What it is: Open-source alternative to survey platforms like Google Forms
    • How we’ll use it (external interface):
    • Get ideas from the code about how we can structure our web application to handle the Site Inspection form

  • Ecorismap

    • What it is: Open-source offline application for recording and checking location information during field surveys
    • How we’ll use it (external interface):
    • Analyze the way the code handles offline data recording and the cross-platform React Native app structure

docs.title: Cloud Services & Infrastructure
docs.text:
• AWS S3
    • What it is: Object storage service for scalable and cost-effective file storage.
    • How we’ll use it (external interface):
    • Store all uploaded site inspection images.
    • Serve images via signed URLs for secure, time-limited access.
    • Separate media storage from the core database to reduce costs.
    • Reference/inspiration: Standard architecture pattern for media-heavy applications.
    • Source of insights: AWS S3 best practices for IAM policies, bucket privacy, and lifecycle rules.
    • Risks/notes: Misconfigured permissions can expose data; billing alerts and access policies will be enforced.

docs.title: About SAPAA
docs.text:
The Stewards of Alberta's Protected Areas Association (SAPAA) applications help stewards, coordinators, and administrators monitor and track site inspections across Alberta's protected areas. Whether you're in the field or at your desk, SAPAA provides the tools you need to:

  • View all protected sites in one place
  • Track when sites were last inspected
  • Review inspection details and trends in naturalness scores
  • Monitor overall program health (Admins only)
  • Manage user accounts (Admins only)

docs.title: Who Should Use This Manual
docs.text:
This manual is written for:

  • Stewards: Field workers who visit and inspect protected areas
  • Coordinators: Program managers who oversee multiple sites
  • Administrators: System managers who handle user accounts and overall program health

You don't need to be technically experienced to use SAPAA. If you can browse websites and use a smartphone, you can use these applications.

docs.title: System Requirements
docs.text:
Mobile App:

  • Android 5.0 or iOS 10.0 or higher
  • At least 100MB of free storage space
  • Internet connection (for initial download and syncing)
  • GPS capability (for map features)

Web App:

  • Modern web browser (Chrome, Edge, Firefox, Safari)
  • Laptop or desktop computer recommended
  • Stable internet connection

docs.title: Creating Your Account
docs.text:
You can create your own SAPAA account or, in some deployments, have one created for you by an administrator.

Option 1: Self Sign-Up (Mobile or Web)

  1. Open the SAPAA mobile app or web app.
  2. On the login screen in the Web, under “Don’t have an account?”, click the “Create one” button. On the mobile App, click "Sign Up".
  3. Choose how you want to create your account:
  4. Continue with Google – sign up using your Google account.
  5. Continue with Microsoft – sign up using your Microsoft / organization account.
  6. Email and Password – enter your email address and choose a secure password.
  7. Follow the on-screen prompts to complete the sign-up process.
  8. After successful sign-up, you will be logged in or redirected to the login screen.

Option 2: Account Created by an Administrator

  1. Contact your SAPAA administrator or coordinator.
  2. They may create an account for you and provide:
    • Your login email address
    • A temporary password (if not using Google/Microsoft sign-in)
  3. You’ll receive login details via email or direct communication.

docs.title: Logging In
docs.text:
You can log in using Google, Microsoft, or email and password.

Mobile App:

  1. Open the SAPAA app on your device.
  2. On the login screen, choose one of the following:
    • Continue with Google – tap and select your Google account.
    • Continue with Microsoft – tap and sign in with your Microsoft / organization account.
    • Email and Password – enter your email address and password, then tap “Login”.
  3. If your credentials are valid, you’ll see the Analytics screen.

Web App:

  1. Open your web browser.
  2. Navigate to the SAPAA web app URL (provided by your coordinator).
  3. On the login page, choose one of the following:
    • Continue with Google – sign in using your Google account.
    • Continue with Microsoft – sign in using your Microsoft / organization account.
    • Email and Password – enter your email address and password, then click “Login”.
  4. If login is successful, you’ll be directed to the Protected Areas page.

First-Time Login Tip: If you received a temporary password, consider changing it to something memorable (contact your administrator for assistance).

docs.title: Understanding User Roles
docs.text:
There are two types of users in SAPAA:

Stewards (General Users):

  • View all protected sites
  • Read inspection details and history
  • Search and sort site information
  • Download sites for offline use (mobile app)
  • Generate site reports (mobile app)

Administrators:

  • All steward features, plus:
  • Access admin dashboard with program-wide statistics
  • View data visualizations and heatmaps
  • Create, edit, and delete user accounts
  • Manage user roles and permissions

How to Tell Your Role:

  • Mobile: Look for the "Admin Dashboard" option in the menu
  • Web: Look for the "Admin" button on the Protected Areas page

If you don't see admin features, you have a steward account.

docs.title: Installing the App
docs.text:
1. Open the Google Play Store (Android) or App Store (iOS)
  2. Search for "SAPAA" or the full name provided by your coordinator
  3. Tap "Install" or "Get"
  4. Wait for the download and installation to complete
  5. Tap "Open" to launch the app

docs.title: Navigating the Mobile App
docs.text:
The app has three main sections, accessible via tabs at the bottom of the screen:

  1. Analytics Tab (📊): View statistics, charts, and search for sites
  2. Sites Tab (📋): Browse, search, and manage the list of protected areas
  3. Map Tab (🗺️): View sites on an interactive map

Menu Options (Top Right, Three Dots):

  • Settings
  • Admin Dashboard (admins only)
  • Logout

docs.title: Viewing Site Analytics
docs.text:
Purpose: Get a quick overview of program status and site health.

Steps:

  1. Tap the Analytics tab at the bottom of the screen
  2. Review the dashboard sections:

Key Performance Indicators (KPIs):

  • Total Sites Inspected: Number of sites with at least one inspection
  • Last Inspection: Date of the most recent inspection across all sites

Naturalness Score Distribution Chart:

  • A pie chart showing how sites are rated:
    • Excellent (green)
    • Good (light green)
    • Fair (yellow)
    • Poor (red)
    • Cannot Answer (gray)
  • Tap any slice to see the count for that category

Site Locator (Heatmap):

  1. Type a site name or keyword in the search bar
  2. Tap "Search"
  3. Sites matching your search appear on the map
  4. Toggle "Show Markers" to switch between heatmap view and individual pins

Refreshing Data:

  • Tap "Sync Now" to manually update all data from the server

docs.title: Browsing and Searching Sites
docs.text:
Purpose: Find and view protected areas you're interested in.

Steps:

  1. Tap the Sites tab at the bottom

Browsing the List:

  • Scroll through the list to see all available sites
  • Each site card shows:
  • Site name (bold)
  • Location/county
  • Last inspection date (or "No inspection date")
  • Status badge (color-coded):
    • 🟢 Recently Visited
    • 🟡 Visited This Year
    • 🟠 Visited Recently
    • 🔴 Needs Review

Searching for a Site:

  1. Tap the search bar at the top
  2. Type part of the site name or location
  3. The list updates automatically to show matching sites
  4. Clear the search to see all sites again

Sorting the List:

  1. Tap the "Sort" button
  2. Choose how you want to organize sites:
    • Name (A-Z): Alphabetical order
    • Name (Z-A): Reverse alphabetical
    • Newest First: Most recently inspected sites first
    • Oldest First: Least recently inspected sites first
  3. The list updates immediately

Understanding Online/Offline Status:

  • Look for the badge at the top of the Sites tab:
    • 🟢 Online: Connected to the internet, showing all sites
    • 🔴 Offline: No internet, showing only downloaded sites

docs.title: Working Offline
docs.text:
Purpose: Access site information when you're in remote areas without internet.

Downloading Sites for Offline Use:

  1. While online, go to the Sites tab
  2. Tap the checkbox (☐) next to each site you want to download
    • You can select multiple sites
  3. Tap the "Download" button (appears when sites are selected)
  4. Wait for the download to complete
  5. A checkmark (✓) appears next to downloaded sites

Using the App Offline:

  • When you lose internet connection, the app automatically switches to offline mode
  • Only downloaded sites will appear in your list
  • You can still:
    • View site details
    • Read inspection reports
    • Generate PDF reports

Managing Storage Space:

  1. Go to the Sites tab while offline
  2. Select sites you no longer need offline
  3. Tap the "Delete" button
  4. Confirm deletion
  5. This frees up space on your device

Tip: Download sites before heading to the field. Common strategies:

  • Download all sites in your assigned region
  • Download sites you plan to visit this month
  • Download frequently referenced sites

docs.title: Viewing Site Details (Mobile)
docs.text:
Purpose: Get complete information about a specific protected area.

Steps:

  1. From the Sites tab, tap on any site card
  2. The Site Detail screen opens

Overview Section:

  • Site Name (large heading)
  • Type: E.g., Provincial Park, Natural Area
  • Region: Geographic area
  • Area: Size in hectares
  • Recreational Activities: Available activities at the site

Naturalness Score:

  • Large number showing the average score (e.g., 3.4)
  • Color-coded slider:
    • Red (1.0): Poor condition
    • Yellow (2.0): Fair condition
    • Light Green (3.0): Good condition
    • Dark Green (4.0): Excellent condition
  • An indicator shows where this site's score falls on the scale

Viewing Inspection Reports:

There are two ways to view inspection data:

Option 1: By Date

  1. Tap "By Date" at the top of the reports section
  2. You'll see a list of all inspections, newest first
  3. Each inspection shows:
    • Inspection date
    • Naturalness score for that visit
  4. Tap any inspection to expand it and see:
    • Steward name
    • Naturalness details (comments)
    • Individual observations (Q1, Q2, Q3, etc.)

Option 2: By Question

  1. Tap "By Question"
  2. You'll see a list of all inspection questions (Q1, Q2, Q3, etc.)
  3. Each question shows:
    • Question ID and text
    • Number of responses across inspections
  4. Tap any question to see how answers have changed over time
  5. Responses are shown from newest to oldest

When to Use Each View:

  • Use "By Date" when you want to read a complete inspection report
  • Use "By Question" when you want to track changes to a specific aspect over time (e.g., "How has trail condition changed?")

Navigating Back:

  • Tap the back arrow (←) at the top left to return to the Sites list

docs.title: Using the Map
docs.text:
Purpose: See where protected areas are located geographically.

Steps:

  1. Tap the Map tab at the bottom
  2. The map loads showing all sites as pins
  3. Zoom in/out using pinch gestures
  4. Tap any pin to see the site name
  5. Tap "Open in Google Maps" to:
    • Launch the Google Maps app
    • Get navigation directions to the site

Requirements:

  • Internet connection (to load map tiles)
  • GPS enabled (for showing your current location)

Tip: Use this before a field visit to plan your route.

docs.title: Generating Reports
docs.text:
Purpose: Create a PDF summary of a site's status and inspection history.

Steps:

  1. Open any site's detail page
  2. Scroll to the bottom
  3. Tap the "Generate Report" button
  4. Wait a few seconds while the PDF is created
  5. The report opens in your device's PDF viewer
  6. From there, you can:
    • View the report on screen
    • Share it via email or messaging
    • Save it to your device

What's Included in the Report:

  • Site overview (name, type, region, area)
  • Naturalness score
  • List of all inspections with dates and scores
  • Detailed observations from recent inspections

Tip: Generate reports before going offline to have them available in the field.

docs.title: Managing Your Profile (Mobile)
docs.text:
Accessing Settings:

  1. Tap the three-dot menu (⋮) in the top right corner
  2. Select "Settings"

Logging Out:

  1. From the menu, tap "Logout"
  2. Confirm you want to sign out

docs.title: Accessing the Web App
docs.text:
Steps:

  1. Open a modern web browser on your computer
    • Recommended: Chrome, Edge, Firefox, or Safari
  2. Navigate to your SAPAA web app URL
    • This is provided by your coordinator (e.g., https://sapaa.yourorg.ca)
    • Bookmark this page for easy access
  3. If you don't have the URL or an account, contact your administrator

After Login:

  • You'll land on the Protected Areas page
  • This is your home screen

docs.title: Viewing Protected Areas
docs.text:
Purpose: See all sites at a glance and quickly identify which need attention.

Understanding the Header:

At the top of the Protected Areas page, you'll see:

  • Title: "Protected Areas" with the SAPAA logo
  • Tagline: "Monitor and track site inspections across Alberta"
  • Admin Button (top right, admins only): Access admin features

Quick Statistics Cards:

Four cards show program-wide stats:

  1. Total Sites: Total number of registered sites
  2. Total Inspections: Number of sites with at least one inspection
  3. Active This Year: Sites inspected in the past year
  4. Needs Attention: Sites not inspected for 2+ years

These give you an instant snapshot of program health.

Searching for a Site:

  1. Click in the search box below the statistics
  2. Type any part of a site name or county name
  3. The site list updates automatically
  4. A line below shows "X sites found"
  5. Clear the search box to see all sites again

Sorting Sites:

  1. Click the "Sort" button
  2. Select an option:
    • Name (A–Z): Alphabetical by site name
    • Name (Z–A): Reverse alphabetical
    • Most Recent: Sites with newest inspections first
    • Oldest First: Sites with oldest inspections first
  3. The list updates immediately

Reading Site Cards:

Each site appears as a card showing:

  • Site Name (bold)
  • County (with location icon 📍)
  • Inspection Date: Friendly format (e.g., "Apr 12, 2024") or "No inspection date"
  • Status Badge (color-coded):
    • 🟢 Recently Visited
    • 🟡 Visited This Year
    • 🟠 Visited Recently
    • 🔴 Needs Review
  • Last Visit Age: E.g., "10d ago", "3mo ago", "2yr ago"

Opening a Site:

  • Click anywhere on a site card
  • You'll navigate to the Site Detail page

docs.title: Exploring Site Details (Web)
docs.text:
Purpose: Get in-depth information about a single site and its inspection history.

Accessing Site Details:

  1. From the Protected Areas page, click on any site card
  2. The URL changes to /detail/[site-name]

Header Section:

  • Back to Sites button (←): Return to the main list
  • Site Name (large, bold)
  • County (with map pin 📍)
  • Last Inspection: Date displayed if available
  • Last Visit Badge: Time since last visit (e.g., "3mo ago")

Site Statistics Cards:

Three cards summarize the site:

  1. Total Reports: Number of inspection records
  2. Avg. Score: Average naturalness score (e.g., 3.2) or "N/A"
  3. Condition: Text label based on score:
    • Excellent
    • Good
    • Fair
    • Poor

Naturalness Score Gradient:

If scores are available, you'll see:

  • Large numeric value (e.g., 3.4)
  • Color gradient bar from red → yellow → green
  • Small indicator showing where this site's average falls
  • Scale labels:
    • 1.0 Poor
    • 2.0 Fair
    • 3.0 Good
    • 4.0 Excellent

Interpretation:

  • Toward red: Site is degraded or disturbed
  • Toward green: Site is in good/excellent natural condition

docs.title: Comparing Inspection Data
docs.text:
Purpose: Analyze inspection history in two different ways.

Switching Views:

Below the Naturalness Score section, you'll see two buttons:

  • View by Date
  • Compare by Question

Click either to switch between viewing modes.

View by Date:

When to Use: Read complete inspection reports one at a time.

What You'll See:

  • Heading: "Inspection Reports (X)" where X is the total count
  • Each inspection is a collapsible card showing:
    • Inspection date
    • Naturalness score for that visit (or "N/A")

Steps:

  1. Click "View by Date"
  2. Click on any inspection card to expand it
  3. You'll see:
    • Steward Name: Who conducted the inspection
    • Naturalness Details: Free-text comments about site condition
    • Observations: Individual question responses (Q1, Q2, Q3, etc.)
  4. Each observation shows:
    • Question ID
    • Answer text from that inspection

Tip: Use this to read through what a steward observed on a specific date.

Compare by Question:

When to Use: Track how a specific aspect has changed over time.

What You'll See:

  • Heading: "Question Comparison (X questions)"
  • Each question is a card showing:
    • Question ID (e.g., Q3) in a badge
    • Question text/label
    • Number of responses (e.g., "3 responses across inspections")

Steps:

  1. Click "Compare by Question"
  2. Click on any question card to expand it
  3. You'll see all responses to that question, sorted newest to oldest
  4. Each response shows:
    • Inspection date
    • Answer text

Example Use Case:

  • Question: "Trail condition"
  • You can see: "Good" (2024), "Fair" (2023), "Good" (2022)
  • This shows the trail has been mostly well-maintained

Tip: Use this to identify trends or recurring issues at a site.

docs.title: Using the Admin Dashboard
docs.text:
Purpose: Monitor program-wide statistics and locate sites geographically.

Who Can Access: Administrators only

Steps to Access:

  1. From the Protected Areas page, click the "Admin" button (top right)
  2. You'll navigate to /admin/dashboard

Dashboard Overview:

The dashboard has four main sections:

1. Header & Summary Stats:

Two cards at the top show:

  • Total Records: Total inspection records in the database
  • Last Record: Date of the most recent inspection

2. Naturalness Distribution (Pie Chart):

  • Shows how all inspections are distributed across naturalness categories
  • Each slice represents:
    • Excellent
    • Good
    • Fair
    • Poor
    • Cannot Answer
  • Slice colors match the condition (green for good, red for poor, etc.)

Use This To:

  • See overall site health across the program
  • Identify if most sites are in good condition or need attention

3. Top 5 Sites (Pie Chart):

  • Shows the five sites with the most inspection records
  • Each slice shows:
    • Site name
    • Total inspection count

Use This To:

  • Identify heavily monitored sites
  • See which sites get the most attention from stewards

4. Site Heatmap (Keyword Search + Map):

Purpose: Locate sites geographically based on search terms.

Steps:

  1. Type a keyword in the search box (e.g., "river", "park", part of a site name)
  2. Click "Search"
  3. The system:
    • Searches for matching sites in the database
    • Counts inspection records for each site
    • Uses geocoding (OpenCage API) to find coordinates
    • Plots sites on the map as a heatmap or markers

What You'll See:

  • If sites are found: Map with colored points or heatmap
  • Below the search bar: "Found X locations for 'keyword'"
  • If no matches: "No sites found"
  • If geocoding fails: Message about locations not being available

Tips:

  • Use short keywords (e.g., "lake" instead of "lakeside recreation area")
  • Try different variations if results are unexpected
  • Use this to identify geographic clusters of certain site types

docs.title: Managing User Accounts
docs.text:
Purpose: Add, edit, and remove user accounts.

Who Can Access: Administrators only

Steps to Access:

  1. Navigate to /admin/account-management
    • Or click the link from the admin menu if available

Header & Summary:

At the top, you'll see:

  • Title: "Account Management"
  • Subtitle: "Manage user accounts and permissions"
  • Add User button (top right)

Three summary cards show:

  1. Total Users: Number of accounts
  2. Admins: Count of administrator accounts
  3. Stewards: Count of steward accounts

Searching for a User:

  1. Click in the search bar labeled "Search by email..."
  2. Type any part of a user's email address
  3. The user list filters automatically
  4. Clear the search to see all users

Filtering and Sorting Users:

  1. Click the "Filter & Sort" button
  2. Choose an option:
    • All Users
    • Email (A–Z)

docs.title: Understanding Naturalness Scores
docs.text:
What is a Naturalness Score?

The Naturalness Score is an average value (typically 1.0 to 4.0) that summarizes how natural or disturbed a site is based on inspection reports.

Score Ranges:

  • 1.0 – Poor: Highly disturbed, significant human impact
  • 2.0 – Fair: Some disturbance, but still functional
  • 3.0 – Good: Mostly natural with minor disturbances
  • 4.0 – Excellent: Pristine, natural condition

How It's Calculated:

  • Each inspection includes a naturalness rating
  • The score shown is the average of all inspections
  • "N/A" means no scores have been recorded

Why It Matters:

  • Helps identify sites that may need restoration or management
  • Tracks whether site condition is improving or declining over time
  • Guides resource allocation for conservation efforts

Where to Find It:

Mobile App:

  • On any site detail page, under the overview section
  • Color-coded slider shows where the score falls

Web App:

  • On any site detail page, in the statistics cards
  • Gradient bar visualizes the score from red (poor) to green (excellent)

Interpreting Trends:

  • If scores are declining: Site may be experiencing increased impact
  • If scores are improving: Management actions may be working
  • Use "Compare by Question" to see what specifically is changing

docs.title: Mobile App Issues
docs.text:
Problem: App Won't Open or Crashes on Launch

Possible Causes:

  • Corrupted installation
  • Insufficient storage space
  • Outdated operating system

Solutions:

  1. Restart your device
  2. Check for app updates:
    • Open the App Store or Play Store
    • Search for SAPAA
    • Tap "Update" if available
  3. Check storage space:
    • Go to device Settings → Storage
    • Free up space if needed
  4. Reinstall the app:
    • Uninstall SAPAA
    • Restart your device
    • Reinstall from the store
    • Log in again

Problem: Cannot Log In

Possible Causes:

  • Incorrect email or password
  • Account not created yet
  • Network connection issue

Solutions:

  1. Double-check your credentials:
    • Ensure Caps Lock is off
    • Verify email is spelled correctly
  2. Check your internet connection:
    • Try loading a website in your browser
    • Connect to Wi-Fi if available
  3. Contact your administrator:
    • They can verify your account exists
    • They can reset your password if needed

Problem: Sites Not Loading or Showing "No Sites Found"

Possible Causes:

  • No internet connection
  • No sites downloaded for offline use
  • Server issue

Solutions:

  1. Check online/offline status:
    • Look at the badge at the top of the Sites tab
    • If offline, only downloaded sites appear
  2. Try syncing:
    • Go to the Analytics tab
    • Tap "Sync Now"
    • Wait for data to refresh
  3. Download sites for offline use (see "Working Offline" section)
  4. If problem persists: Contact your administrator

Problem: Map Not Loading

Possible Causes:

  • No internet connection
  • GPS disabled
  • Map service issue

Solutions:

  1. Check internet connection: Map tiles require internet
  2. Enable GPS:
    • Go to device Settings → Location
    • Turn on location services
    • Allow SAPAA to access location
  3. Try again later: Map services occasionally have outages

Problem: Cannot Generate PDF Report

Possible Causes:

  • Insufficient device permissions
  • Low storage space
  • Missing data

Solutions:

  1. Check app permissions:
    • Go to device Settings → Apps → SAPAA
    • Ensure storage permissions are granted
  2. Free up storage space
  3. Ensure the site has inspection data: Reports require at least one inspection

Possible Causes:

  • Database permissions issue

  4. Delete them from offline storage
  5. Download them again (this gets the latest data)

docs.title: Frequently Asked Questions
docs.text:
Q1: What's the difference between a steward and an admin?

A:

  • Stewards can view all sites, read inspection details, search and sort data, and generate reports (mobile app).
  • Admins have all steward features plus access to the Admin Dashboard (statistics, heatmap) and Account Management (create/edit/delete users).

Q2: What does "Needs Attention" mean?

A: A site is flagged "Needs Attention" (or "Needs Review") when it hasn't been inspected for approximately 2 years or more. This signals to coordinators that the site may need a new visit.

Q3: Why do some sites say "No inspection date"?

A: This means no inspection date has been recorded in the database for that site. Possible reasons:

  • It's a newly added site
  • It's an older record without a date
  • Inspections were conducted but dates weren't entered

Q4: What is the Naturalness Score?

A: The Naturalness Score is an average value (1.0 to 4.0) summarizing how natural or disturbed a site is based on inspection reports:

  • 4.0 = Excellent: Pristine, natural condition
  • 3.0 = Good: Mostly natural, minor disturbances
  • 2.0 = Fair: Some disturbance
  • 1.0 = Poor: Highly disturbed

Higher values indicate better natural conditions.

Q5: Can I change my own password?

A: This depends on your deployment configuration. If you don't see a "Change Password" or "Reset Password" option in the app or web interface, contact your SAPAA administrator for assistance.

Q6: How do I download sites for offline use?

A: (Mobile app only)

  1. Go to the Sites tab while online
  2. Tap the checkbox next to sites you want to download
  3. Tap "Download"
  4. Sites are now available offline

Q7: Why doesn't a site show up on the heatmap?

A: Possible reasons:

  • The site name didn't match your search keyword
  • The site couldn't be geocoded (no coordinates found)
  • Temporary issue with the geocoding service

Try a different keyword or contact an admin.

Q8: How often should I sync the mobile app?

A: It depends on your workflow:

  • Daily field use: Sync daily or before heading out
  • Occasional use: Sync weekly or before important meetings
  • After major updates: Sync immediately if you know new data was added

Q9: Can I use the mobile app without internet?

A: Yes, but with limitations:

  • You must download sites while online first
  • Only downloaded sites are available offline
  • You can view details, read inspections, and generate reports
  • You cannot sync new data or access the map

Q10: Who do I contact if I have a problem?

A: Contact your SAPAA program coordinator or system administrator using the contact information provided by your organization.

Q11: How do I know which version of the app I'm using?

A: (Mobile app)

  • Go to device Settings → Apps → SAPAA
  • The version number is listed there

Q12: Can I access SAPAA from a tablet?

A:

  • Mobile app: Yes, if you have an Android or iOS tablet
  • Web app: Yes, any device with a modern web browser can access it

Q13: What happens if I lose internet connection while using the web app?

A: You'll see error messages when trying to load data. Reconnect to continue. The mobile app is better suited for offline field work.

Q14: How do I report a bug or suggest a feature?

A: Contact your SAPAA coordinator with details about:

  • What you were trying to do
  • What happened instead
  • Which device/browser you were using

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This document explains how UI design principles, usability heuristics, and accessibility considerations were applied in both the SAPAA mobile application (React Native) and web application (Next.js). The goal is to provide an intuitive, accessible, and efficient experience for environmental stewards and administrators managing site assessment data.

docs.title: Visual Consistency
docs.text:
Principle: Maintain a consistent visual language to reduce cognitive load and build user confidence.

Implementation:

  • Unified navigation shell

    • Mobile: All screens use the same green top app bar with title + back button. A persistent bottom tab bar provides access to: Analytics, Sites, and SAPAA Map.
    • Web: Consistent header with SAPAA logo, gradient green background, and navigation elements. Admin pages use a hamburger menu for navigation.

  • Standardized colour palette

    • Primary green (#2E7D32, #356B43, #254431) for headers and primary actions.
    • White (#FFFFFF) for content cards and main background.
    • Light grey (#F7F2EA, #E4EBE4) for dividers and secondary surfaces.
    • Red (#B91C1C, #DC2626) for destructive actions (e.g., Delete Account).
    • Gradient backgrounds (from-[#F7F2EA] via-[#E4EBE4] to-[#F7F2EA]) for visual depth.

  • Typography hierarchy

    • Page titles: large, bold (24-32px).
    • Section headers: medium, semi-bold (18-20px).
    • Body text: regular weight (14-16px).
    • Supporting text: smaller, regular (12-14px).

docs.title: Clear Visual Hierarchy
docs.text:
Principle: Guide attention using size, weight, colour, and spacing.

Implementation:

  • Card-based layout

    • Major information chunks are grouped into cards (e.g., Site Details, Naturalness Details, Analytics charts, Account tiles).
    • Cards have consistent padding, rounded corners, and subtle shadows.

  • Strategic emphasis

    • Primary actions use filled green buttons with high visual weight (e.g., Preview PDF, Sync Now, Login).
    • Secondary actions use outlined buttons or lower-contrast styling.
    • Critical information like site names and scores appears in larger, bolder text.

  • Consistent spacing

    • Padding inside cards (16-24px) and consistent vertical spacing between sections (16-32px) creates rhythm and improves readability.

docs.title: Progressive Disclosure
docs.text:
Principle: Show only what users need at each step, and reveal more detail on demand.

Implementation:

  • Inspection Reports

    • Tabs for By Date and By Question instead of putting all data into one long view.
    • Expandable sections for detailed observations.

  • PDF generation (Mobile)

    • Modal flow: choose fields → preview report → optionally share/download.

  • Site Details

    • High-level information at the top (name, location, key metrics).
    • Detailed observations, naturalness details, and other sections appear further down the page in separate cards.

  • Admin Features

    • Admin-specific features are hidden from regular users.
    • Admin navigation is accessible via menu or dedicated button.

docs.title: Action-Oriented Design
docs.text:
Principle: Make key tasks obvious and easy to complete.

Implementation:

  • Clear primary action per screen

    • Preview PDF on the report modal (Mobile).
    • Sync Now on Analytics (Mobile).
    • Search on Sites/Protected Areas pages.
    • Delete Account on Admin tiles (clearly styled in red).

  • Button hierarchy

    • Primary: solid green, often full width.
    • Secondary: outlined or low-emphasis.
    • Destructive: red, clearly labelled.

  • Immediate feedback

    • PDF field counter updates as checkboxes are toggled (Mobile).
    • Tabs highlight the active state.
    • Lists and cards visually respond to taps/clicks.
    • Loading states show progress indicators.

docs.title: 1. Visibility of System Status
docs.text:
Heuristic: The system should always keep users informed about what is going on.

Application in SAPAA:

  • Mobile:

    • Field counter in the PDF modal (e.g., 14 of 14 fields selected) updates live as users toggle checkboxes.
    • The app bar title reflects the current screen (e.g., Site Details, Report).
    • Bottom navigation highlights the active tab.
    • Sync actions provide visual feedback while data is refreshing.
    • Online/Offline badge shows connection status.

  • Web:

    • Loading spinners appear during data fetches.
    • Page titles reflect current location.
    • Active navigation items are highlighted.
    • Search results show count (e.g., "X sites found").

Why This Matters: Users can see that their actions are working and where they are in the app, which reduces confusion and frustration.

docs.title: 2. Match Between System and the Real World
docs.text:
Heuristic: Speak the users' language and use real-world concepts.

Application in SAPAA:

  • Uses real steward terminology: Naturalness Score, Recreational Activities, Observations.
  • Mobile: SAPAA Map uses Google Maps with familiar map interactions.
  • Web: Leaflet maps provide familiar zoom and pan interactions.
  • Icons:
    • Tree (🌲) for Sites.
    • Chart (📊) for Analytics.
    • Map (🗺️) for SAPAA Map.
    • Eye (👁️) for Preview PDF.
    • Calendar (📅) for dates.
    • Map Pin (📍) for locations.
  • Inspection questions are labelled with codes (Q52, Q62, etc.) that stewards already know.

Why This Matters: Familiar language and visuals reduce training time and make the app feel like a natural extension of existing workflows.

docs.title: 3. User Control and Freedom
docs.text:
Heuristic: Provide clearly marked exits and ways to undo actions.

Application in SAPAA:

  • Mobile:

    • Back arrow on every top bar to return to the previous screen.
    • Modals can be dismissed with an X or the system back gesture.
    • Users can toggle PDF fields freely.
    • Use Select All and Clear All before committing.
    • Preview a report before sharing it.

  • Web:

    • Back buttons on detail pages.
    • Modal dialogs can be closed with X button or clicking outside.
    • Cancel buttons on forms.
    • Breadcrumb navigation where applicable.

Why This Matters: Users feel safe exploring features because they know they can easily back out or adjust their choices.

docs.title: 4. Consistency and Standards
docs.text:
Heuristic: Follow platform conventions and maintain internal consistency.

Application in SAPAA:

  • Mobile:

    • Consistent bottom navigation layout across screens.
    • Primary actions are always solid green buttons; destructive actions are always red.
    • List items follow the same pattern: icon left, label and detail text right.
    • Card layouts and spacing follow a consistent grid.

  • Web:

    • Consistent header design across all pages.
    • Button styles are standardized (primary, secondary, destructive).
    • Form inputs follow the same styling.
    • Card components are reused throughout.

Why This Matters: Once users learn basic patterns, they can apply them everywhere in the app.

docs.title: 5. Error Prevention
docs.text:
Heuristic: Design to prevent errors before they happen.

Application in SAPAA:

  • Mobile:

    • PDF flow separates Preview PDF and Share PDF so users don't accidentally share a report before checking it.
    • Destructive actions such as Delete Account are clearly styled in red and can be guarded by confirmation dialogs.
    • Many inputs are constrained to checkboxes and predefined fields instead of free text for critical data.
    • Labels on buttons and fields are explicit (e.g., Delete Account, Share PDF).

  • Web:

    • Form validation prevents invalid submissions.
    • Confirmation dialogs for destructive actions.
    • Disabled states prevent invalid actions.
    • Clear error messages guide users.

Why This Matters: Preventing mistakes saves time and protects data integrity.

docs.title: 6. Recognition Rather Than Recall
docs.text:
Heuristic: Minimize the user's memory load by making options visible.

Application in SAPAA:

  • Clear labels for all fields: Region, Area (HA/AC), Naturalness Details, etc.
  • Mobile: Bottom tabs always visible with both icons and text labels.
  • Web: Navigation menu items are clearly labeled.
  • PDF field selection list mirrors the Site Details layout and naming (Mobile).
  • Question lists show IDs and titles instead of expecting users to remember them.
  • Status badges show inspection recency with color coding.

Why This Matters: Users don't have to remember information across screens; they can simply recognize it.

docs.title: 7. Flexibility and Efficiency of Use
docs.text:
Heuristic: Provide accelerators for expert users while keeping the interface simple for novices.

Application in SAPAA:

  • Bulk actions

    • Select All / Clear All for PDF fields (Mobile).
    • Sync Now for on-demand data refresh (Mobile).
    • Bulk selection for offline downloads (Mobile).

  • Multiple access paths

    • Inspection reports can be viewed:
      • By Date (chronological workflow).
      • By Question (comparison/analysis workflow).

  • Quick navigation

    • Mobile: Bottom tab bar offers one-tap switching between Analytics, Sites, and SAPAA Map.
    • Web: Admin menu provides quick access to all admin features.

  • Smart defaults

    • PDF generation starts with all fields selected, so users usually only need to deselect a few (Mobile).
    • Search is always available.
    • Sort options are remembered.

  • Larger devices

    • On tablets and larger screens, standard OS gestures and shortcuts are respected.
    • Web: Responsive design adapts to different screen sizes.

Why This Matters: New users can follow straightforward flows, while experienced users can speed up their work with bulk actions and shortcuts.

docs.title: 8. Aesthetic and Minimalist Design
docs.text:
Heuristic: Interfaces should not contain irrelevant or rarely needed information.

Application in SAPAA:

  • Focused screens: each screen supports one main task (view analytics, inspect a site, manage accounts, generate PDF).
  • Limited colour palette: green, white, grey, and red for warnings.
  • Cards group only related information, with enough white space for breathing room.
  • Icons are only used where they add meaning (e.g., map pin, chart, tree), not for decoration.
  • Web: Clean, modern design with ample whitespace.
  • Mobile: Material Design principles with clear visual hierarchy.

Why This Matters: A clean interface makes it easier to focus on what matters and reduces cognitive overload.

docs.title: 9. Help Users Recognize, Diagnose, and Recover from Errors
docs.text:
Heuristic: Error messages should be expressed in plain language, indicate the problem, and suggest a solution.

Application in SAPAA:

  • Mobile:

    • Error messages appear as snackbars/toasts with clear explanations.
    • Network errors show retry options.
    • Validation errors appear inline with form fields.
    • "No sites found" messages suggest checking search terms or connection.

  • Web:

    • Error messages are displayed in red, clearly visible.
    • Form validation shows specific field errors.
    • Network errors provide retry buttons.
    • 404 pages guide users back to main content.

Why This Matters: Users can quickly understand what went wrong and how to fix it, rather than feeling frustrated.

docs.title: 10. Help and Documentation
docs.text:
Heuristic: Help should be easy to search, focused on the user's task, list concrete steps, and not be too large.

Application in SAPAA:

  • User manual is available (separate document).
  • In-app tooltips and hints where appropriate.
  • Clear labels and placeholders guide users.
  • Status messages explain what actions do (e.g., "Syncing data...").
  • Web: Contextual help through clear page titles and descriptions.

Why This Matters: While the interface should be self-explanatory, having documentation available helps users learn advanced features.

  • Color Contrast: Text meets WCAG AA standards (4.5:1 for normal text, 3:1 for large text).

docs.title: 8. Conclusion
docs.text:
The SAPAA applications (both mobile and web) follow established UI/UX principles to create an intuitive, accessible, and efficient experience for stewards and administrators. Key strengths include:

  1. Consistent Design Language: Both platforms share color schemes, typography, and interaction patterns while respecting platform conventions.

  2. Clear Information Architecture: Hierarchical organization makes it easy to find and understand information.

  3. Progressive Disclosure: Complex information is revealed gradually, preventing cognitive overload.

  4. Accessibility: Both applications meet WCAG standards and support assistive technologies.

  5. Responsive Design: Web application adapts to various screen sizes, while mobile app supports tablets and phones.

  6. Error Prevention and Recovery: Clear validation, error messages, and confirmation dialogs protect users from mistakes.

  7. Efficiency Features: Bulk actions, shortcuts, and smart defaults help experienced users work faster.

The design prioritizes the needs of field stewards who may be working in challenging conditions (poor connectivity, mobile devices) while also supporting administrators who need comprehensive data views and management tools.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The SAPAA Web Application is a Next.js 16 application that provides a web interface for stewards and administrators to view and manage protected area inspection data. The application uses:

  • Next.js 16.0.1 - React framework with App Router
  • Supabase - Database and authentication service
  • OpenCage Geocoding API - For location-based features
  • Vercel - Deployment platform

Deployed URL: https://sapaa-webapp.vercel.app/

  6. Git (for cloning the repository)

docs.title: Setting Up Row Level Security (RLS)
docs.text:
Supabase uses Row Level Security to control data access. You may need to configure RLS policies:

  1. Go to Authentication → Policies in Supabase
  2. Create policies for each table to allow:
  3. Authenticated users to read data
  4. Admins to read/write data (if applicable)

Example Policy:

-- Allow authenticated users to read sites
CREATE POLICY "Allow authenticated users to read sites"
ON sites_list_fnr
FOR SELECT
TO authenticated
USING (true);

docs.title: User Roles Setup
docs.text:
The application uses Supabase Auth user_metadata to store user roles. Roles are stored in the user_metadata.role field of each user.

How Roles Work: - Default role: steward (assigned automatically if no role is set) - Admin role: admin (must be set manually) - Roles are stored in: user.user_metadata.role

Setting Admin Role:

  1. Go to Supabase Dashboard → Authentication → Users
  2. Find the user you want to make an admin
  3. Click on the user to edit
  4. In the Raw User Meta Data section, add or update: json { "role": "admin" }
  5. Click Save

Note: New users created through the app's signup page will default to steward role. Only admins can change user roles through the Account Management interface.

docs.text:

  • [ ] All environment variables are set in Vercel (not in code)

  • [ ] Default passwords are changed
  • [ ] Row Level Security (RLS) is enabled on Supabase tables
  • [ ] API rate limiting is configured (if needed)
  • [ ] CORS is properly configured in Supabase
  • [ ] SSL/HTTPS is enabled (automatic with Vercel)
  • [ ] Error messages don't expose sensitive information
  • [ ] Authentication is required for all protected routes
  • [ ] Admin routes are properly protected
  • [ ] No console.log statements with sensitive data in production

docs.title: API Documentation
docs.text: The web application exposes the following API endpoints:

docs.title: 1. Geocoding API
docs.text:
Endpoint: GET /api/geocode

Description: Geocodes a location name to coordinates using OpenCage API.

Query Parameters: - q (required): Location name to geocode

Example Request:

GET /api/geocode?q=Elk Island Provincial Park

Example Response:

{
  "latitude": 53.5731,
  "longitude": -112.8583
}

Error Response:

{
  "error": "Missing q param"
}

Status: 400

Rate Limits: - Limited by OpenCage API quota (2,500 requests/day on free tier)

docs.title: 2. Heatmap API
docs.text:
Endpoint: GET /api/heatmap

Description: Searches for sites matching a keyword and returns counts for heatmap visualization.

Query Parameters: - keyword (optional): Search term to match against site names

Example Request:

GET /api/heatmap?keyword=park

Example Response:

{
  "data": [
    {
      "namesite": "Elk Island Provincial Park",
      "count": 15
    },
    {
      "namesite": "Writing-on-Stone Provincial Park",
      "count": 12
    }
  ]
}

Empty Response:

{
  "data": [],
  "message": "No sites found"
}

Error Response:

{
  "error": "Database query failed"
}

Status: 400 or 500

Authentication: - Requires authenticated user session (handled by middleware)

docs.title: 3. Authentication Endpoints
docs.text:
These endpoints are handled by Next.js and Supabase:

  • POST /login - User login
  • POST /signup - User registration
  • GET /auth/callback - OAuth callback handler
  • GET /auth/confirm - Email confirmation handler

Note: These are internal API routes. Use the frontend login/signup pages instead of calling these directly.

docs.title: Updating Dependencies
docs.text:
1. Check for outdated packages:
npm outdated
  1. Update specific packages:
npm update <package-name>
  1. Update all packages (use with caution):
npm update
  1. Test thoroughly after updates
  2. Commit package-lock.json changes
